Ablam A., nicknamed «Pétit» (or Tiny), was born on December 31, 1982 in Ghana. He only finished grade school before entering an apprenticeship with the goal of becoming a master shoemaker. Today, he owns his own shop that he runs honestly and with discipline. Having suffered a lot due to his parents being poor, he works incessantly to struggle with life’s difficulties. His talents allow him to properly meet the expectations of his customers, and he is highly valued in his neighborhood. As a result of this encouragement, he started producing different kinds of shoes, bags and purses, belts, and other goods that he sells in the marketplaces of Tabligbo. This business, which could be very profitable for him, has had trouble developing because he does not have enough capital at his disposal. The shoes that he makes are highly appreciated in the marketplace, and he even receives orders from Lomé, the capital city. He really needs financial support to be able to bolster and develop his business.

And so he is requesting a loan of $850 as capital to buy a machine and some materials of the trade in order to produce and sell shoes, bags, belts, etc. The success of his plans will allow him to improve living conditions for him and his parents. Financing this very devoted young man will be a fine example for other young people, so that they may follow in his footsteps and advance themselves in life.

Translated from French by Daniel Kuey, a Kiva Volunteer.

Monsieur A. Ablam dit « Petit » est né le 31 décembre 1982 au Ghana. Il n’a fait que des études primaires avant d’aller en apprentissage au bout duquel il devient maître cordonnier. Il tient aujourd’hui son propre atelier qu’il gère avec rigueur et honnêteté. Ayant beaucoup souffert à cause de la pauvreté de ses parents, il travaille sans relâche pour lutter contre les difficultés de la vie. Ses talents lui permettent de satisfaire convenablement ses clients et il est très bien apprécié dans quartier. Fort de cela, il a commencé par produire des chaussures de différentes gammes, des sacs, des ceintures et autres qu’il vend sur les marchés de Tabligbo. Cette activité qui peut lui être très rentable a du mal à se développer car M. A. n’a pas un capital consistant. Ses chaussures fabriquées sont bien appréciées sur le marché et il reçoit même les commandes depuis Lomé. Il a vivement besoin d’un appui financier pour pouvoir renforcer et accroître son activité. Il sollicite alors un crédit de $850 qui lui permettra d’acheter une machine et de matériel de travail afin de produire et de vendre des chaussures, des sacs des ceintures etc. Le succès de ce projet permettra à M. A. d’améliorer ses conditions de vie et celles de ses parents. Financer ce jeune homme très dévoué sera un bel exemple pour d’autres jeunes à emboîter ses pas pour leur autopromotion.

loans.use: Buy a machine and material in order to produce and sell shoes

payments.comment:
Madam Ablam thanks sincerely KIVA and all those who have contributed to her project funding which allows her today to increase her activities and automatically her incomes to her proper living conditions improvement and those of her family. May Almighty and Merciful God bless you, and rendered it to you everlastingly!!!
The credit is repaying normally and without any incident at this moment.

loans.name: Kokou

texts.en:
Born in 1958 in Tabligbo in Yoto prefecture, Kokou G. ended his studies at the grade school level. Married and the father of six children, he is a welder by trade and currently own his own shop with a dozen apprentices. He is highly valued and renown in the city of Tabligbo because of the broad experience he has acquired in this trade, as well as for the quality of his work. He has complete control of his business, and his fine work is undeniably. This only brings in more customers! But Mr. G. only has at his disposal some worn and outdated tools that make his work slow and difficult. He has trouble meeting the expectations of his customers right now, and he seriously risks losing them. He therefore is seeking funds to upgrade his equipment and have a steady supply of work materials.

To do this, he is requesting a loan of $950 as capital for new and modern tools and to buy materials for his work. This will allow him to satisfy his customers on a timely basis and to make a substantial income for the welfare of his family.

Translated from French by Farron Blanc and Daniel Kuey, Kiva Volunteers.

Né en 1958 à Tabligbo dans la préfecture de Yoto, Monsieur G. Kokou a arrêté ses études au cours primaire. Marié et père de six (06) enfants, il est soudeur de formation et tient aujourd’hui son propre atelier avec une dizaine d’apprentis. La grande expérience qu’il a acquise dans ce métier et la qualité de ses prestations font de lui un soudeur très bien apprécié et de renommée dans la ville de Tabligbo. Il a une parfaite maîtrise de ses activités et ses prestations sont sans reproche. Ce qui ne fait qu’augmenter sa clientèle. Mais, Monsieur G. ne dispose que des outils vétustes qui rendent le travail lent et pénible. Il a du mal à satisfaire tous ses clients aujourd’hui et risque fort de les perdre. Il recherche alors des moyens pour renforcer son équipement et disposer permanemment du matériel de travail.

Pour ce faire, il sollicite un crédit d’un montant de $950 qui servira à acquérir des outils nouveaux et modernes et acheter du matériel pour son travail. Ceci permettra de satisfaire à temps sa clientèle et de disposer d’un revenu consistant pour le bien-être de sa famille

loans.use: Acquire new modern tools and buy material.

payments.comment:
Kokou Gogri thanks sincerely KIVA and all those who have contributed to his project funding which allows him today to increase his activities and automatically his incomes to his proper living conditions improvement and those of his family. May Almighty and Merciful God bless you, and rendered it to you everlastingly!!!

The credit is repaying normally and without any incident at this moment.

loans.name: Afi

texts.en:
Afi G. was born on August 13, 1965 in Tabligbo. She did not have the opportunity to go to school because her parents were slow to understand the necessity of educating a girl. She currently sells basic daily necessities (groceries). Married and the mother of three, she is also the guardian of two other children. Household expenses became more burdensome, and her meager income was insufficient. The family now lives in poverty. Her husband lacks a steady job and does not help with the bills very much. Ms. GAGA finds herself trapped by these responsibilities and does not know what to do anymore. Despite her courage and will, her family falls prey to daily problems. She had benefited from a $450 loan that she handled and repaid in a satisfactory manner. A very energetic woman brimming with confidence, she is in need of financial support to bolster and grow her small business. Therefore, she is requesting a loan of $850 as capital to acquire fish and grocery items to sell. Financing this business means contributing to the struggle against poverty in deprived areas.

Translated from French by Farron Blanc and Daniel Kuey, Kiva volunteers.

Madame G. Afi est née le 14 août 1965 à Tabligbo. Elle n’a pas eu la chance d’aller à l’école car ses parents n’ont pas vite compris la nécessite de la scolarisation d’une fille. Elle a aujourd’hui comme activité le petit commerce de vente des produits de première nécessité (épicerie). Mariée et mère de trois (03) enfants, elle a à sa charge deux (02) autres enfants. Les charges du ménage devenant plus lourdes que le maigre revenu de Mme GAGA, la misère s’est installée dans la famille. Son mari qui n’a pas un emploi fixe ne contribue pas efficacement aux charges du ménage. Elle se trouve écrasée par les charges et ne sait plus à quel saint se vouer. Malgré son courage et sa volonté, son ménage est en proie à des difficultés quotidiennes. Elle bénéficia alors d’un crédit de $450 qu’elle avait su bien gérer et rembourser sans incident. Très dynamique et pleine de confiance, elle a besoin d’un appui financier pour renforcer et accroître son petit commerce. Elle sollicite, pour ce faire, un crédit de $850 qui servira de fonds de commerce pour l’achat et la revente du poisson et des produits d’épicerie. Financer cette activité, c’est contribuer à la lutte contre la pauvreté des milieux démunis.

loans.use: Buy and sell fish and food products.

loans.name: Essrou

texts.en:
Essrou A. was born in 1978 in Ahépé in Yoto prefecture. He is married and has a child. After leaving grade school, he entered an apprenticeship to be an automobile electrician, a trade he has mastered perfectly. With his modest savings, he succeeded in opening a shop in Tabligbo. Despite his impeccable work, he has trouble meeting customer expectations on time because he only has very basic equipment. The situation has begun to discourage customers, so he could lose a good part of his customer base. This has already had serious repercussions for his household, since his income is insufficient to cover all his bills. To perfect and grow his business, Mr. A. has a pressing need to acquire new equipment, in order to better serve and regain the trust of his customers. This requires financial means he currently does not have at his disposal. So, he is requesting a loan of $850 as capital for modern tools to equip his shop, thereby enhancing his business. This will allow him to augment his income and, from there, improve the living conditions of his family.

Translated from French by Farron Blanc and Daniel Kuey, Kiva volunteers.

Monsieur A. Essrou, né en 1978 à Ahépé dans la préfecture de Yoto, est marié et père d’un (01) enfant. Après avoir abandonné ses études au cours primaire, il entra en apprentissage pour sortir électricien automobile, un métier qu’il maîtrise avec perfection. Avec ses modestes moyens, il réussit à ouvrir un atelier à Tabligbo. Malgré son travail assez impeccable, il a du mal à satisfaire à temps ses clients car son équipement est rudimentaire. Cette situation a commencé par décourager les clients et peut lui amener à perdre une bonne partie de sa clientèle. Ce qui a déjà des répercussions sérieuses sur son ménage car le revenu est ne suffit pour couvrir entièrement les charges du foyer. Pour parfaire et accroître ses activités, Monsieur A. Essrou a un besoin pressant d’acquérir de nouveaux équipements afin mieux servir et reconquérir sa clientèle. Ceci nécessite des moyens financiers qu’il ne dispose pas à ce jour. Il sollicite à cet effet un crédit de $850 qui va lui servir à acquérir des outils modernes pour l’équipement de son atelier et le renforcement de son activité. Ce qui permettra d’augmenter son revenu et partant, améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.

loans.use: Acquire modern tools for his workshop.

loans.name: Délali Virginie

texts.en:
A. Délali Virginie A. is 34 years old. After she completed her masters degree in sociology at the University of Lomé, she served in a local NGO earning a pitiful and intermittent salary. Now then, she is responsible for her elderly parents and her two children still in school. So, she decided to use her small savings to start a business in order to pay her bills. Starting with $550, which includes a $350 loan she repaid on time, she began her grocery business, which she calls «Virginia». With a high level of intellect, she keep good accounting records, and there is transparency in her management. With her work experience, she has come to make business another specialization of hers. Today, the development of her business requires precise financing. She is requesting a loan of $1,000 to add to her capital in order to grow her grocery business, thus allowing her to augment her income. This will serve to improve the living conditions of her family.

Translated from French by Daniel Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

Mlle A. A. Délali Virginie est aujourd’hui âgée de 34 ans. Après sa maîtrise en sociologue à l’université de Lomé, elle a servi dans une ONG de la place avec un salaire dérisoire et irrégulier. Or, elle a à charge ses parents aujourd’hui très âgés et ses deux petits encore étudiants. Elle décida alors d’initier une activité génératrice de revenu avec sa petite économie réalisée afin de faire face à ses charges. Elle commença alors le commerce d’alimentation générale avec $550 dont un crédit de $350 parfaitement remboursé. Son niveau intellectuel lui permet de tenir une bonne comptabilité et il y a une clarté dans sa gestion. Avec cette expérience, elle se fait une autre spécialisation de commerçante. Le développement de son commerce nécessite aujourd’hui, un financement d’appoint. Aussi, sollicite-t-elle un crédit de $1000 pour renforcer son capital pour accroître son commerce d’alimentation générale. Ce qui lui permettra d’augmenter ses revenus qui serviront à l’amélioration du niveau de vie de ma famille.

loans.use: Add to her capital and improve her food store.

payments.comment:
Madam Delali Virginie thanks sincerely KIVA and all those who have contributed to her project funding which allows her today to increase her activities and automatically her incomes to her proper living conditions improvement and those of her family. May Almighty and Merciful God bless you, and rendered it to you everlastingly!!!

The credit is repaying normally and without any incident at this moment.

loans.name: Zulfura

texts.en:
She is Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-ocupied territory of  Azerbaijan Fizuli region, settled in Absheron region, has 2 children.  
She has been engaged in this business for 8 years. 
Zulfura sells women’s clothes. She borrowed a loan amount of $500 and bought street clothes. 
Now she needs a loan amount of $1000 to be busy with selling the street clothes and industrial goods. She supports her family with this business. 
She is very optimistic about the future of her business.

loans.use: To start selling industrial goods

loans.name: Rovshan

texts.en:
Rovshan has been engaged in this business for 5 years. This 25-year-old young man is Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-ocupied territory of  Azerbaijan Fizuli region, settled in Khirdalan settlement. He is married,  has 2 children. In the beginning of his business he borrowed a loan amount of $500, which he spent to rent a medicine-chest and to start selling optic glasses.
Now he needs a loan amount of $1000 to increase range of goods.
This medicine-chest has been provided with the medicinal preparations by firm.

loans.use: To increase range of goods

loans.name: Vugar

texts.en:
Vugar sells of fruits and vegetables in his own car. He has not a shop. This car is his own. His car did not not work good. He had a problem with his car. This problem disturbed to him to expand his business.
Having borrowed a loan amount of $400, he repaired his car and bought the fruits and vegetables.
The second loan $800 he spent to buy 4 wheels and 1 accumulator and increased the amount of the fruits and vegetables. 
Vugar was born in 1969. He is married, has 1 child.
He is Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-ocupied territory of  Azerbaijan Fizuli region Mirzenagilli village. He and his family settled in Khirdalan settlement.
Now he needs a loan amount of $1200 to build a shop. He plans to be busy with sale agricultural products

loans.use: To build a shop

loans.name: Mehdi

texts.en:
Mehdi is internally Displaced Person ( IDP ) from the Armenian-ocupied territory of Azerbaijan Gubadli. He settled with his family on hotel of railway station In the city of Sumgayit. 46-year-old Mehdi has 3 children. Before he wanted to open his own market, he could not do it. Is the only breadwinner in family. 4 years ago he has rented a minishop of railway station. He borrowed the loan amount of $200 to buy the foodstuffs. The borrowed his second loan $500 he spent to increase the foodstuffs. 
Now he applies for the loan of $1000 to increase the foodstuffs.

loans.use: to increase the foodstuffs

payments.comment: The repayment were paid back timely. No delinquency.

loans.name: Solmaz

texts.en:
Solmaz was born in 1951. She is is Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-ocupied territory of  Azerbaijan Fizuli region, settled in Khirdalan settlement, married, has 3 children.
Having borrowed a loan amount of $400, she had bought medicinal preparations and started her business. 
This medicine-chest has been provided with the medicinal preparations by firm.
In the beginning of her business she could not buy the medicinal preparations for cash from firm.
For the second time she borrowed a loan amount of $800 and bought a lot of medicinal preparations for cash.
For the third time she borrowed a loan  of $1000 and bought all medicinal preparations for cash.
Now she needs a loan amount of $1200 to privatize this medicine chest .
She has been engaged in this business for 20 years.

loans.use: To privatize a medicine chest

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-ocupied territory of  Azerbaijan Lachin region, settled in Khirdalan settlement. 
He has been engaged in this business for 9 years.
This shop is not his own, he has rented it. 
Having borrowed a loan amount of $400, he started to sell children’s clothes.
For the second time he borrowed a loan amount of $600 
to sell  the children’s clothes and woman’s blouses.
For the third time she borrowed a loan  of $800 to sell blankets.
Now he needs a loan  of $1200 to expand the area of his shop and to increase range of industrial goods.

loans.use: To expand the area of his shop

loans.name: Farhad

texts.en:
You can see a young man, who is enjoying with his business. He is a very kind, friendly and hard-working person. 
This 39-year old man is Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-ocupied territory of  Azerbaijan Fizuli region. He is married, has 2 children, settled in a dormitory of Yasamal region, which is located in Baku city.
He has run this business for 10 years.
Komak Credit Union help to him to begin his business.
Having borrowed a loan amount of $800, he bought tea-house equipments: tables, tea-pots, cups.
He has a lot of plans.
Farhad works very hard to bring about his plans.
Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy 2 conditioners, 2 billiard-tables.
He desires to have the tea-house with all conveniences.
Farhad tries to create the good conditions for his clients in his tea-house.

loans.use: To buy 2 conditioners, 2 billiard-tables, to do capital repairs of his own tea-house

loans.name: Lawrence

texts.en: Lawrence is married with two children. He started his business making and selling bicycle parts three years ago after failing to find work.  He raised the initial capital from the sale of farm produce on his family land. With the first loan from PEMCI he was able to boost his business and to buy himself a small piece of land. Life has greatly improved for him and his family. With this second loan of US$150 he plans to diversify his stock of bicycle parts to include larger components. Bicycle transportation is the major mode of transportation in this part of the country and demand for spare parts for repair and maintenance is high. This is a much needed service to the local community and the economy at large.

loans.use: Buy Bicycle parts

loans.name: Moses

texts.en: Moses is married with 5 children, 2 in secondary school. He has received some basic training in entrepreneurship from World Vision. He started his motorbike transportation business 2 years ago after raising some cash from tobacco sales. He has now been able to raise some cash from the business to purchase a second motorbike. The loan of US450 from PEMCI is to make up for the shortfall. With the two motorbikes operational he will be able to repay the loan without fail. Motorbike transportation is emerging as a quicker alternative to bicycle transportation known as Boda Boda. The Motorbikes are used to ferry passengers long distances that the bicycles cannot reach. This emerging alternative will have a very positive and effective impact on the economy and the communities in the area.

loans.use: To buy an Additional Motorcycle

loans.name: Doriine

texts.en: N. is a single mother of two. She dropped out of school when she got pregnant and became a mother. For her to survive, she had to get some sort of source of income.  She operates a vegetable stand outside her mother’s house where she also lives with her two children. She got her first loan from PEMCI and started the food vending business. With the second loan of $150 she plans to boost her business further and to improve on her income. This will enable her provide for her children and educate them.

loans.use: Vegetable seller

loans.name: Bernard

texts.en: Bernard is a primary school dropout and has no formal training. He is not yet married but he supports his younger sisters, one in primary school and the other in secondary school. In 2001, Bernard received the equivalent of $51 from his Uncle to start a hawking business, following failure to raise school fees.  With the loan of $150 from PEMCI, he intends to boost his stock in order to improve his income.  He is a very confident young man and we believe he has a good future with us.

loans.use: Buy Assorted Items for Hawking

loans.name: Janerose

texts.en: Janerose is Married with Eight children. All are in school. The husband is a retired labour officer. She started her grains and flour Business in 1999 to support her family’s needs. With the help of her first loan of $90 from PEMFI she was able to stock her business and support all her Children in Primary School. With the second loan of $150 she plans to boost her stock further to improve her income and service to her local community. She also plans  to start an animal feed Business to broaden her income base. She hopes to get a bigger loan in future to support her grain selling business. She has a big vision of her future.

loans.use: To Buy More Stock

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: Joseph is physically handicapped, married with four children. He does tailoring and selling of finished tailored clothes at Ang’urai Market. Through his business, he is able to support his family. The loan from PEMCI of US$150 will enable him stock some fabrics which he can make and sell ready made garments. The loan will empower him to be more self-sufficient despite his handicap.

loans.use: Tailor

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose is married with four children, two of them in primary school. She started her shop business two years ago after selling her tobacco harvest. She started the shop so as to compliment/support her husband’s income. The shop is doing well and with the loan of US$150 from PEMCI she intends to build up her stock and improve profitability. She intends to quit the tobacco growing business due to its health hazards.

loans.use: Stock Shop

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter is married with two children. Before starting his business four years ago, he was just a laborer for a timber cutter. He continued saving while gaining experience on how to operate and maintain a power saw. In 2000, he bought his own power saw and now he splits his own timber and supplies the nearby centers. With the loan of US$150 from PEMCI he intends to stock his own timber for resale to furniture makers and builders.

loans.use: Timber Merchant

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Madam Patience O. lives in the Dodowa community of the Greater Accra region of Ghana. She sells mainly yams and other agricultural produce, including groundnuts and beans. The demand for her goods increases daily. Madam Patience is a very hardworking woman who wishes to sell more than she is doing now but lacks capital. She is therefore seeking a loan of $850.00 from Kiva to help expand her business. She is also very good in keeping records and loan management, all of which was learned from KSFs TEACH product.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Theophilus

texts.en: Mr. Theophilus I. is the manager of Goodnews Communication & Minibar. He has lots of customers who will have to queue anytime they visit his shop before they have their turn. This is because he doesnt have enough phones as well as tables and chairs to work with. Mr. I. is greatly worried by this and is therefore seeking a loan of $875.00 from Kiva to help him out of this situation and expand his business.

loans.use: working capital to buy phones and other furniture

loans.name: John

texts.en: Mr. John A. is a photographer located in Dodowa, a community in Accra. Due to the nature of services he provides, which is producing quality pictures, he always has a list of orders on his desk. He however, doesnt have enough cameras to help meet his customers demands. He is seeking a loan of $800.00 from Kiva to buy more cameras, film, and batteries. He is also a beneficiary of KSFs TEACH product and can effectively manage this loan without fail.

loans.use: working capital to buy cameras, film, and batteries

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Charcoal is the main source of fuel energy for domestic use in rural Ghana. Janet sells charcoal to a community of 3,000 inhabitants. Her sales are good and she enjoys much patronage from the people. She hopes to receive a Kiva loan of $925 to improve her charcoal sales.

loans.use: working Capital to improve her charcoal selling business

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en: Madam Paulina D. is the owner of the With God Retail Shop. She sells items such as soaps, sugar, washing powder, sweets, tins of milk, fish etc. The demand for her goods in her locality is very high. She however, doesnt sell all the items that she wishes to sell. Even the items that she sells are not enough because Madam Paulina D. is a very hardworking woman and it has been her desire to own a bigger shop and sell more goods. She is seeking a loan of $800.00 from Kiva to fulfill this desire. She is also very capable of paying back the loan.

loans.use: to expand the items sold in her retail shop

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Rebecca sells charcoal to a large number of people and institutions within her locality. These institutions include schools, clinics and small enterprises in her vicinity. Rebecca experienced high sales during the Christmas festivities. She wants Kiva loan of $1150 to expand her business.

loans.use: working capital to expand her charcoal selling business

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en: Hannah is a beekeper. She breeds bees for making honey and sells them to health institutions and schools within the community. Hannahs honey is one of the best produced in the community. She has a large market consisting of phamarceutical shops located near her locality. She needs the loan to improve the production of honey in her combs.

loans.use: to increase the production of honey

loans.name: Hanna

texts.en: Hantet Local Foods is noted for its sumptuous Ghanaian dishes particularly banku and kenkey. These are both staple foods prepared from maize. Faithful customers of Madam Hanna T. will not live a day without visiting her bar. She has limited cooking pots, stoves and other equipment for the smooth running of her bar. She also needs capital to renovate the area where customers sit to enjoy their meal. She is therefore appealing to Kiva to grant her a loan of $750.00 to enable her to buy the items needed to meet the high demand. Madam Hanna T. will in no way disappoint Kiva in paying the loan back because she is very hardworking and has good loan management capabilities.

loans.use: working capital to buy equipment for her bar and to renovate the dining area

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Madam Comfort L. sells utensils. She carries her wares in a small tray on her head and moves from one place to another. It is her desire to own a shop and sell more of the utensils. She is therefore seeking a loan of $950.00 from Kiva. She is also very hardworking and will put this loan to good use.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Philomina

texts.en: Madam Philomina D. is very dynamic and sells items ranging from fashionable earrings, necklaces, bangles, perfumes, powder, combs, hair accessories, etc but on a very small scale. She would very much like to own a shop and include more items. She is seeking a loan of $900.00 from Kiva to help her put up a shop and sell more items. Her zeal to work harder all the time cannot be over-emphasized, she can indeed pay back every penny.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Gifty

texts.en: Madam Gifty N. lives in Dodowa, a community in the Dangme West district of the Greater Accra region of Ghana. Madam Gifty N. has eyes for beautiful things. This is the reason why she sells beautiful African prints and everyone wishes to buy from her. She however doesn\'t have a shop where her numerous customers can locate her at a particular point in time. She is therefore seeking a loan of $900.00 from kiva to grow her textile trade and satisfy her customers. She also has good management skills and will not be found wanting when paying back.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en: Naomi H. is the operator of Lomnava Eating Place. She cooks delicious meals for sale to her customers. She is always on time and her surrounding is neatly kept. This has won her the admiration of most people generating loyal customers. She however, has limited capital to cook more to meet this high demand. She is humbly seeking a loan of $750.00 from Kiva to expand her operation.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Emily

texts.en: Madam Emily L. prepares nutritious khebabs made from soy beans for sale. The nutritional value of soy bean creates a high demand for her khebab by both young and old. She wishes to produce more on a larger scale for all to have their fair share. Lack of capital is her limitation. She is hopeful that Kiva will grant  her a loan of $700.00 to help her operate as she wishes. She is very good in loan management and simple record keeping.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Vida

texts.en: Peace & Love Enterprise is a very vibrant shop supplying its numerous customers with a whole lot of items. Madam Vida L. operates on a daily basis working tirelessly from dawn to dusk. She however, wishes to re-stock her shop to include more items than she currently has now. She is therefore seeking a loan of $800.00 from Kiva. She is a beneficiary of KSF\\\'s TEACH Product and knows about loan management.

loans.use: re-stocking capital

loans.name: Tuch

texts.en:
C. Tuch is a 48 year old wife and mother. She has two daughters and two sons. For work, C. Tuch cleans a fruit called tarmine. She peels the fruit from the outside covering, so that it is ready to be sold. She earns about $1.75 per day from this. C. Tuch\'s husband works on house construction and earns $3.75 per day. One son sells newspapers and earns about $5 a day. Her other son works for a company that purifies drinking water and earns a salary of $30.25 a month. One of her daughters sells fruit and earns about $3.75 per day. The whole family helps to contribute to the family income.

C. Tuch is requesting a loan of $700 to purchase materials to repair their home and to purchase a new motorbike. This will allow them to improve their home to make it more safe and comfortable. The motorbike will help them to increase their income because they will no longer have to rely as much on moto taxis for their transportation and it will assist in transporting the materials and products for their businesses. C. Tuch is excited about the possibility of improving her and her family\'s lives through this loan.

loans.use: Repair home and purchase motorbike

payments.comment:
Congratulations to Tuch Chear who closed her loan early! Thank you making this loan possible. We appreciate your ongoing support of poor Cambodian entrepreneurs and our clients.

Best regards,
Jordyan Edmiston, Kiva Fellow
& the entire CREDIT MFI team

loans.name: Moses

texts.en: Moses is married with 5 children, 2 in secondary school. He has received some basic training in entrepreneurship from World Vision. He started his motorbike transportation business 2 years ago after raising some funds from tobacco sales. He now wishes to buy a second motorbike. He has been able to raise some funds from the business toward the purchase, and the loan of US$450 from PEMCI is to make up for the shortfall. With the two motorbikes operational he will be able to repay the loan without fail. Motorbike transportation (known as Boda Boda) is emerging as a quicker alternative to bicycle transportation. The motorbikes are used to ferry passengers long distances that the bicycles cannot reach. This emerging alternative will have a very positive impact on the economy and the communities in the area.

loans.use: To Purchase A Motorcycle

loans.name: Moses

texts.en: Moses is married with 5 children, 2 in secondary school. He has received some basic training in entrepreneurship from World Vision. He started his motorbike transportation business 2 years ago after raising some funds from tobacco sales. He now wishes to buy a second motorbike. He has been able to raise some funds from the business toward the purchase, and the loan of US$450 from PEMCI is to make up for the shortfall. With the two motorbikes operational he will be able to repay the loan without fail. Motorbike transportation (known as Boda Boda) is emerging as a quicker alternative to bicycle transportation. The motorbikes are used to ferry passengers long distances that the bicycles cannot reach. This emerging alternative will have a very positive impact on the economy and the communities in the area.

loans.use: To Purchase A Motorcycle

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en: Ms Lilian K. is a designer by profession and operates a clothing shop where she also sells crafts made by local artisans from local materials. The plants used in weaving these local baskets, chairs, and trays are unique to this area. The loan of US$450 will enable Ms Lilian to increase her stock of these items, hence promoting this local industry. She plans to promote the sale of these items outside the local area and even for the export market. Because the plants are harvested from along the rivers at no cost, the weaving industry would constitute a very viable source of income for the local community. PEMCI is very keen to support this type of innovative project, which would benefit the local community, enabling them to overcome poverty.

loans.use: Designer & Businesswoman

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Ms Grace W. is a single mother of 4. She runs a hotel business, and also sells clothing and household fabrics to supplement her income and help her meet the education needs of her children. The $450 loan will enable her to increase the stock of bed sheets, bed covers, etc. which she sells to customers who come from as far away as the neighboring country of Uganda. She anticipates a good profit margin from this cross-border trade in clothing and fabrics. Her vision is to open a large warehouse shop in the near future so that she can buy things in bulk for sale.

loans.use: Purchase Stock of Household Fabrics for Sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to start an internet cafe

loans.name: Rev. Salapio  Mulei

texts.en: Mr  M.  is a pastor of a local church and wishes to start a poultry raising and selling business (broilers) to supplement his income. He has requested a PEMCI loan of US$450, which will enable him buy 500 young chicks and the accompanying feed and medication. His wife and son will work with him on the project. The calculated return on the investment is good, and he should be able to repay the loan within the six months and also grow the business. Mr M. is a very well known and respected member of his community and PEMCI is confident of his ability and determination to repay the loan. With income from the poultry business he will able to support his family and to meet the needs of his young church. His objective is to employ some of  the youth in his church on the project. He also intends to use this project as a demonstration to encourage others in the community to venture into the business. We find this to be a worthwhile venture to support.

loans.use: Poultry Raising and Trade

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to expand his computer sales business

loans.name: Shem

texts.en: Mr Owande is married with five children, 4 in secondary school. He owns a pick-up truck, with which he harvests sand from a nearby river and sells it to construction sites to support his family. He also works as a farmer to meet his family food requirements, makes building bricks for sale, and transports goods for market traders to supplement his income. He employs several young men who work with him in these projects. He needs the loan from PEMCI of US$725 to buy some essential spare parts to service his vehicle. The building industry is a key sector of the economy here, and sand and building bricks are its essential components. Mr Owande is making an important contribution to the larger economy and the local community by creating employment and income.

loans.use: Sand Seller, Brick Maker & Transporter

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to expand her livestock business

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en: Daniel is a mobile phone and electronics parts hawker/vendor. He conducts his business along the busy Kenya-Uganda highway and sells most of his products to truckers and other travelers. He is married with 4 children. Since leaving school, he has done all sorts of businesses to earn a living.  The loan of US$450 is intended to help him expand his hawking business and eventually open a little shop. With sufficient cash he also plans to travel to the city of Nairobi, where he can buy electronics cheaper and hence improve his profitability. He eventually hopes to become a wholesaler. Daniel was introduced to us by his brother-in-law, who is a long-term client of PEMCI and also his guarantor. This loan would be of great advantage to this young man with big ambitions.

loans.use: Mobile Phone/Electronics Hawker/vendor

loans.name: Judith

texts.en: Judith is a widow with 2 children who are in primary school. Her husband passed away in 2001. She has some basic training in the area of health care and operates a small chemist (pharmacy) in her rural village. She intends to use the loan of US$300 from PEMCI to stock her chemist and to boost her business’s profitability. This being the only health care facility in her village, Judith is playing a very key role in supporting the well-being of her community. She is also distributing free Malaria drugs under a Government program.

loans.use: Chemist (Pharmacy) Owner

loans.name: Aggrey

texts.en: Aggrey is married with eight children and his wife is a housewife. Since starting his cereal grains business four years ago, he is able to support his family, and has also managed to support his church orphanage. With the loan of $300 from PEMCI, he plans to open up a new shop at Malakisi trading centre, which will improve his services and broaden his capital base in the cereal grains business.

loans.use: cereal grains seller

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to expand his business of selling eggs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to expand his carpentry business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to expand his food kiosk

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Madam Grace L. owns a shop in which she sells vegetables, sugar, washing powder, toothpaste and the like. Her shop is doing well but she wishes she could provide more than she is now. She also has a lot of customers who buy from her. Madam Grace L. is faced with the problem of limited capital to grow her business. She is therefore seeking a loan of $750.00 from Kiva to re-stock her shop. She can keep simple records, manage loans effectively: all of which were acquired through KSF\\\'s TEACH product. She can use this loan well and pay it back easily.

loans.use: re-stocking capital

loans.name: Sandra

texts.en: Madam Sandra K. D. sells both cassava and corn dough. She sells them in little quantities(retail) but it is her desire to sell them in bags and include other items in her trade. She is therefore seking a loan of $750.00 from Kiva. This will help her work harder than before and to her satisfaction.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Mavis

texts.en: Madam Mavis A. sells soap. She markets her goods by moving from home to home. She lacks capital to increase or expand and is more often than not idled when her goods get finished in good time. This poses a problem to her since she loves to be working all the time. Madam Mavis believes that when she gains more capital to work with, her soap business will grow and improve her living condition. She is therefore seeking a loan of $700.00 from kiva.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en: J\'s Batik Tye & Dye is noted for producing beautiful batik and the popular tie & dye. This has won her the admiration of all and for that matter a lot of customers. Madam Jennifer A. is the fourth lady (from left) in the picture without a certificate. Those with certificates are graduants from her institute. There is a high demand for fabric but cannot meet this demand due to lack of capital to buy ingredients for production like calico, dye, caustic soda, gloves, pots and so on. She is seeking a loan of $775.00 from kiva to help meet the demand of her beloved customers. She is a very hardworking lady who can pay back this loan.

loans.use: working capital
